title: 106_s2440
content: The "Airport Security Improvement Act of 2000" may be cited as the short title. Criminal history record checks are addressed in the Act. Expansion of FAA Electronic Pilot Program to include criminal history record checks into an aviation industry-wide program within 2 years of enactment. Participation in the program is not mandatory for airports, air carriers, or screening companies if they determine it is not cost-effective. The Administrator must provide a report on the status of efforts to implement the program within a year of enactment. If the program is not operational after two years, the Administrator must notify the relevant committees. Changes in existing requirements for criminal history record checks for individuals applying for certain positions in air transportation security are outlined in the amendment to Section 44936(a)(1) of title 49, United States Code. This includes removing certain language and specifying the need for criminal history record checks for screeners and others applying for relevant positions. In the first 2 years of a 3-year period, a criminal history record check can be conducted for up to 45 days before completion. In the third year, the check can be done for up to 30 days before completion. The employment investigation is not required for individuals who have completed a criminal history record check before starting a specific position. After enactment, individuals applying for positions at Category X airports must undergo a background check within 30 days, while those at other airports subject to part 107 requirements must do so within 3 years. Section 44936(b)(1)(B) of title 49, United States Code, is amended to include new offenses barring employment, such as felonies involving threats or unarmed felonies. The list of offenses that bar employment includes willful destruction of property, importation or manufacture of a controlled substance, burglary, theft, dishonesty, fraud, misrepresentation, possession or distribution of stolen property, aggravated assault, bribery, and illegal possession of a controlled substance punishable by a maximum term of imprisonment of more than 1 year. Improved training is outlined in section 3, with a specific amendment regarding clauses in the paragraph. Improved training standards for screeners are mandated by an amendment to Section 44935 of title 49, United States Code. The Administrator is required to issue a final rule on certification of screening companies by May 31, 2001, with a minimum of 40 hours of classroom instruction for security screeners. The final rule may allow individuals to qualify for security screening services by completing a program equivalent to classroom instruction. Additionally, individuals must complete 40 hours of on-the-job training and pass an examination before exercising independent judgment as a security screener. The Administrator will ensure that computer-based training facilities for security screeners at airports are conveniently located and easily accessible. SEC. 4. IMPROVING SECURED-AREA ACCESS CONTROL. Section 44903 of title 49, United States Code, is amended to include guidelines for disciplining employees who violate airport access control requirements, with sanctions such as remedial training, suspension, or termination of employment. Each airport operator, air carrier, and security screening company must adhere to these guidelines. The security program for airport operators, air carriers, and security screening companies must include sanctions for violations and a process for disciplining employees who breach airport access control requirements. The Administrator will collaborate with these entities to enhance controls by January 31, 2001, and mandate comprehensive training programs for employees on their security roles and responsibilities. The curr_chunk discusses the requirements for airport operators and air carriers to develop programs that promote compliance with access control regulations, conduct assessments for compliance, improve the security database, and enhance the execution of security measures. The curr_chunk requires airport operators and air carriers to strengthen access control points in secured areas by January 31, 2001 to ensure passenger and aircraft security. SEC. 5. PHYSICAL SECURITY FOR ATC FACILITIES. The Administrator of the Federal Aviation Administration must address physical security weaknesses at air traffic control facilities to obtain accreditation by April 30, 2004. Follow-up inspections and prompt corrections are required to maintain accreditation. Reports on progress must be submitted annually to relevant committees. The report discusses progress in improving physical security at air traffic control facilities and the percentage of facilities with security accreditation. SEC. 6. EXPLOSIVES DETECTION EQUIPMENT. Section 44903(c)(2) of title 49, United States Code, is amended to require a manual process at airports with underutilized explosive detection equipment. This process will randomly select additional checked bags for screening to enhance security measures. The Administrator shall seek to maximize the use of explosive detection equipment for screening checked bags to enhance security measures. SEC. 7. AIRPORT NOISE STUDY. Amendment to Section 745 of the Wendell H. Ford Aviation Investment and Reform Act for the 21st Century involves replacing the Comptroller General of the United States with the National Academy of Sciences for an agreement. Subsection (b) is modified by removing certain paragraphs and redesignating others. The Wendell H. Ford Aviation Investment and Reform Act for the 21st Century is amended by replacing the Comptroller General with the National Academy of Sciences for a study on airport noise. A report must be submitted to the Secretary within 18 months, who will then share it with Congress. Authorization of appropriations is provided for this purpose. SEC. 8. TECHNICAL AMENDMENTS. Technical amendments were made to various sections related to Federal Aviation Management Advisory Council, National Parks Air Tour Management, and Restatement of Provision Without Substantive Change in title 49 of the United States Code. The text chunk discusses regulations regarding air carriers providing scheduled charter air transportation for aircraft with more than 9 passenger seats. The regulations require flights to and from airports with specific operating certificates. There is an exception for airports in Alaska and outside the United States. SEC. 9. EFFECTIVE DATE: This Act and its amendments will take effect 30 days after enactment.
